div.sent: It has bean made possible due to the advancement of science and technology.
The present age is said to be the evolutionary age of science and technology.
A country is as developed in science and technology as wealthy it is and the standard of living depends on these.
Perhaps the discovery of electricity has brought about the most influential changes to our life.
Now, just use the switch and there is light, and the fan starts moving.
Many home appliances like the fridge, air conditioner.
television set, washing machine, VCR, telex, fax, computer etc. are run by electricity.
These things have made our life easy and comfortable.
Think a while and you will understand what contribution science and technology have in meeting our fundamental needs of food, clothing, housing, health and education.
Farmers in the past used to depend on the will of nature for cultivation;
they had to wait for rain.
Now irrigation by pumping water has made it possible to cultivate lands in time.
The uses of power-tiller and various types of manure have increased productions of crops by many times.
Even in the deserts crops are being produced by the help of irrigation.
Crops are protected from various harmful insects by using pesticides.
Cold storage facilities enable farmers to store their products for a long time.
As a result we can now have potato, tomato and other seasonal vegetables and fruits all the year round.
Thus, science and technology is helping us meet the demand of ever increasing food sector.
Various artificial clothes such as nylon , rayon, tetron etc. Science and Technology in Everyday Life 167 meeting our demands of clothing.
Cement, rods, bricks etc. gave us means to raise sky scrappers.
We can make economic use of our lands by using the technology of building multi-storied houses.
It is said that health is the root of all happiness.
Health is wealth.
Science has valuable contributions to health sectors to protect us from diseases, to prevent untimely deaths and to ensure long life.
Diseases like malaria, cholera, pox, plague etc. are now removed from our world.
Ask your father, grand father; and you will know how thousands of people used to die every year due to these diseases.
It has been possible now to prevent diseases like measles, polio, whooping cough, diphtheria, and tetanus with the discovery of vaccines.
The discovery of x-ray, echocardiogram, ultrasonogram, endoscope, scanners have led to the correct and timely diagnosis of many diseases.
Now, transplantation of heart and kidney are also possible.
Cornea grafting gives blind people vision.
In the field of transportation and communication Science has brought revolutionary changes.
We can comfortably and quickly go from one place to another by car, railway or aeroplane.
A distance which took months to go takes only few hours now.
You can send a message to your near and dear ones by telephone instead of going there in person.
By telephone youcan talk not only to your friends in the country but you can talk to people anywhere in the world.
There are other means of communicating with people far away from you as you can use telex and fax too.
Radio and television are wonderful inventions of science.
For example, distant learning academic courses are now being offered through radio and television.
Thus, it is clear that in all spheres of life we apply science and technology and enjoy their blessings.
But still we all can not enjoy the fruit of Science and technology.
This is due to the fact that science and technology have not been properly promoted in our country.
We must study science, digest it thoroughly and make proper use of it.
Appropriate technology necessary for our country should be innovated and applied to faster the process of development.
All of you have seen and used radio.
It is run by battery and easy to carry.
People sometimes call it transistor too.
But actually transistor is not a radio, it is only a component of radio.
The invention of transistor has paved the way of making radio.
It has made radio portable and has lessen its electricity consumption.
Thus the name radio was replaced by transistor.
Again by radio we mean a machine used to hear music or news.
But that is not the fact; radio is a useful device to facilitate communication.
Radio communication system has got a sound transmitter and a receiver.
The sound that is sent by a transmitter may be of music, news or talks.
The radio we use in our house is actually a receiver.
In a radio station a transmitter is installed.
Radio transmitter and receiver may be of various sizes and of arious strengths.
You may have seen walky-talky used by the police officers.
This has both the functions of a transmitter and a receiver.
But by such radios communication is not possible between two far places.
These radios can communicate within a limited range.
There are radio transmitters and receivers in ships by which communications with other ships or planes are maintained.
Radio is a machine which converts sound into electricity and again electricity into sound.
In a radio transmitter a microphone is used to convert sound into electricity.
This electricity is then amplified again and again by an amplifier and a strong electromagnetic wave is produced.
With the help of an antenna this electromagnetic wave is spread to the surrounding space.
The function of the loud speaker is opposite to that of a microphone.
Microphone converts sound into electricity while the loudspeaker converts electricity into sound and we hear the sound earlier converted by microphone to electricity.
By a television we can see picture and hear sound at the same time.
Like radio, television has a transmitter.
Transmitters are stationed at the television centre.
The transmitter has two parts; one is for sound transmission and the other for picture transmission.
The transmission and reception of sound is almost like that of a radio.
Picture is taken by a television camera.
The camera screen converts the picture that falls on it into electricity i.e. here light energy is transformed into electrical energy.
This electrical energy is spread into the space by the antenna of the transmitter in the form of electromagnetic wave.
This wave is received by the antenna of our television sets which is nothing but a receiver.
As the antenna catches the wave, it send it as electricity to the different parts of the television set.
Finally it appears in out television screen as the original picture that had fallen on the television camera.
There is good matching between picture and sound so that we hear the appropriate sound with appropriate picture.
After taking a picture by a television camera, we can preserve it in a tape.
This is known as video recording and the tape is called video cassette.
This cassette can be run by VCP or VCR and the recorded picture and sound appears on the television screen.
Generally wedding programmes, birthday parties and other important events are recorded in cassette which is later seen by VCP or VCR.
The cinema, drama, and musical functions anything can be recorded this way and later can be seen.
As in television news, recorded pictures with sound of important events are shown along with the news.
On television screen, with the help of satellite, we can see almost all the important and interesting events taking place across the globe.
Although we use television as a means of recreation its role in generating information is even greater.
Television is also used to educate people.
A teacher can teach thousand of students through it and the learners can attend thoselessons sitting at their own places.
Television is an example of such educational programme.
Moreover, we can develop our knowledge by watching the talk shows where eminent intellectuals express their views on issues of national and international importance.
Another wonderful invention of modern science is computer.
The use of computer is increasing day by day in the world as it has made doing work easier.
It is unparallel in doing work rapidly and skillfully.
Computer is being widely used in the office, bank, industry, hospital, educational institution etc.
Even we use personal computers at our houses.
Computers can be big or small not only in terms of its look but in terms of its capacity.
There are three main parts of a P.C- input, output and central processing unit (CPU).
The input looks like a keyboard of a type writer.
By this key board computer is put into action.
The central processing unit (CPU) looks like a flat box.
It is the brain of the computer.
It works on the direction given by the key board.
The output portion is a small television screen.
It is called monitor.
The result of the direction that a key board gives is seen in monitor accordingly.
A computer works very fast without making any mistake and can store a large amount of information.
That is why it is widely used.
Computer can be used for various purposes.
Some of the uses are: Typing:- This is called word processing.
By computers we can compose a document quickly and accurately.
As a result, it increases the skills and speed of our office work.
Storing of information:- Many people work in an office.
Records about each employee such as their date of joining, date of birth, salary, date of increment etc. are stored in a computer.
In a business organization all kinds of financial information regarding utility bills, money transactions, clients dues are stored and organised by computers.
In medical services:- Computer is used to diagnose an illness.
Fully computerised diagnostic units are now operating in some hospitals and clinics in our country.
Moreover, computers are being used in operating complex surgeries.
In Industries: Computers are used in manufacturing industries to control the quality of products and to check the demand and supply of goods.
In transport sector: Now a days railway and air tickets are being booked or sold by computers.
Bangladesh Railway has already computerised its ticketing system.
Computers are also used in road traffic control and automatic take off and landing of aeroplane.
Even many of the fuel/gas stations are fully run by computers.
In military operations: Computers are now being used in penetrating the enemy target in war.
It is also used to build military hardware.
In research: For research works scientists use computer.
It is used to collect, process and analyse data.
Complex mathematical solutions are also done very quickly by computers.
In public examinations: Thousands of candidates appear in public examinations like SSC or HSC each year.
It is very difficult to evaluate the answers scripts and prepare results of such a huge number of candidates each year.
Now a days, the marking of SSC answer scripts and preparation of results are being done by computer.
In printing industry: Computer has valuable contributions to printing industry.
It is widely used for composing, setting, designing of books, journals and news papers.
Computers have revolutionised our printing industry.
Telex and fax are two very modern ways of communication.
Telex and fax have numbers like telephone.
There is a typewriter with the telex.
The information, news or letter to be sent is typed by this type writer.
Now send it to the desired telex number; the typed message is received at the receiver's end.
Fax machine has a telephone attached to it.
The information to be sent is written by hand or typed on a piece of paper.
The desired number is dialled and the piece of paper with the information is entered into the fax machine.
A photocopy of the document comes out of the fax machine at the receiver's end.
Texts, pictures, maps or any other documents can be sent by the fax.
Energy comes to us from the sun as heat and light.
The heat is used to dry cloths, paddy, jute etc.
This heat can be used to cook our food also.
For this the sun rays are to be concentrated at a certain point.
The place around the concentrating point will be hot enough to cook food.
Sun rays are reflected by bright metal disks in the shape of a pan and is concentrated directly under the cooking pot.
Heat cannot be controlled in a solar cooker and it cannot be used at night and cloudy days.
So it is not used widely.
But it has some advantages too; the solar energy is renewable, it does not cost any fuel and it does not pollute our environment.
Moreover, it helps us in saving our limited sources of energy such as coal, fuel and gas.
In the villages of Bangladesh cowdung, dry straw, grass and other easily putrescent refuses are used as fuels.
These refuse is not very much healthy.
These make the cooking pots and clothes dirty.
Moreover, while using these refuse, the heat received is not fully used and so cooking takes a long time.
Scientists have found that if these putrescent refuse is fermented in a airtight vacuum, then a gas is produced.
This is called biogas.
About 60-70 percent of this gas is composed of methane which is an excellent fuel.
Rest of the gas is mainly carbon di-oxide.
Biogas can be produced not only from cowdung but also from stool and urine of the hen, goat, ship etc. and from rotten water plants.
Beside these, cars can be run on this gas.
It can be used in preserving food grains and fruits too.
The remains after producing biogas is a good organic manure.
It is also used in fisheries and pearl production.
Another advantages of biogas is, it does not pollute the environment.
Though animal excrements are used in biogas plant, it does not spread bad odour or does not have any unhygienic effect.
Biogas is a source of renewable energy.
It can play an important role to meet the energy crisis of Bangladesh.
The oven used in rural Bangladesh wastes 85-90 percent of available energy, only 10- 15 percent energy is utilised by it.
The characteristics of an improved oven are: The improved oven has short leg only about half an inch height.
So much heat is not lost through the space in between legs.
There is a sieve or strainer at a small distance nside the oven.
So the fire above the sieve completely heats the cooking ot.
There are holes bellow the sieve; air can go inside through these holes and completely burns the fuel.
As a result no unburnt fuel remains except ashes.
There are various types of improved ovens: Some are portable, some have sieve and some are sieveless.
There are ovens built completely under the ground having one or two mouths.
Some ovens are fitted with chimney.
Some of these ovens are suitable for hotels where a large quantity of food is prepared.
Some ovens use fire wood only.
Again there are ovens where all kinds of fuel like fire wood, straw, cow-dung cake, sawdust etc. are used.
Improved ovens can easily be made of clay.
